blog.name: cutlike-a-buffalo
blog.title: Never for money, always for love.

summary: Why Jonerys stans think that EW cover it's like a confirmation of their ship, a win over Jonsa? We're in denial? Honey, we have...
body:
Why Jonerys stans think that EW cover it’s like a confirmation of their ship, a win over Jonsa? We’re in denial? Honey, we have been watching the show. Why do they need that cover to confirm their ship so desperately? Jonerys doesn’t need to prove it’s real. We all saw s7 😂 It’s natural they’re on that cover and they will be in 1000 more covers. We know Jonerys is real. We know they fucked but they’re NOT ENDGAME. GoT will never go for the obvious endgame and certainly they wouldn’t put in bold on a cover before the season starts. You just bit the bait 😏

Some Jonerys stan commented on my previous post and she is comparing the Jonsa hug with their cover. Sweety, we know Jonsa is not real yet, we ship it, squint and analyze. But we know it’s not confirmed. If they compare the Jonsa hug with the cover it’s because they really feel Jonsa is a possibility, it triggers them. Why do they get so agitated for something that is not real that they think they have to prove their ship to feel better? That attitude is the one making Jonsa more real for me. Why would they be so triggered by a 3 sec hug of a non confirmed ship? Another one commented “bring s8 trailer” so we can see Jon and Dany together… I mean, we know that, of course they’re going to be together in the trailer. Why wouldn’t they?

The Jonsa hug doesn’t scream endgame or confirmed ship as the EW cover. That hug actually was made to think Sansa is so mad and that she is going to betray Jon. We Jonsas analyzed the hug and took it as a part of our ship. Why would they fight with us If they are so sure their ship is endgame?

We Jonsas don’t deny Jonerys exists. Jonerys is real. There will be many more covers and merch. And of course they will be together in teasers and the s8 trailer!! They’re just not endgame.

I ship Jonsa, for me it started like my own unpopular opinion just based in the chemistry Sophie and Kit have as actors and because they look cute together since s6 (I’ve been rooting for Dany since s1) .And because I think Sansa deserves a good love interest. I started analyzing and I actually think Jonsa makes sense and it is fun to think of it, fanfictioning it. Just like I ship Eowyn and Aragorn. “What If they…” and I started to make my own story.

In my personal opinion. Since s1 I knew Jon and Daenerys were going to meet and get together at some point. It was predictable like in all stories the protagonists get together. It actually was necessary for the storyline. I know Jonerys is real, I know Jon cares for her because Jon is noble, a hero. Honestly. My hopes for Jonsa to happen are really high in my fan heart, a plot twist that shocks the audience. But being neutral I know it might not happen. But also as a GoT fan and being objective I feel Jonerys is gonna be short lived. GoT is not a fairy tale. GoT is cruel and bittersweet. To me the song of ice and fire reffers to Jon only. Jon is the main character of the story. Not Dany. GoT has been teaching lessons to all characters. Dany has been so consumed with the idea that the 7 Kingdoms are hers, she even thinks she is the one of the prophecy. Which means in the end she is going to sacrifice all of that. Dany is probably going to die for someone or the realm itself. Jonerys is not endgame.

And actually that cover confirms it. Game of Thrones has been retweeting and sharing that cover on their official sites. They have spent almost 2 years and millions to make this final season spectacular and shocking, with the highest security to prevent leaks. They wouldn’t spoil the real endgame that way. That’s a marketing strategy. They want to hype and generate expectations and make all the possible profit of this.

Dany has been so consumed with the idea that the 7 Kingdoms are hers, she even thinks she is the one of the prophecy. Which means in the end she is going to sacrifice all of that. They have spent almost 2 years and millions to make this final season spectacular and shocking, with the highest security to prevent leaks. They wouldn’t spoil the real endgame that way. summary: The Song of the Winter Rose
title: The Song of the Winter Rose
description:
by xxitisbluexx

Jon sabe que debe darle algo de crédito, después de todo Arya había aparecido en las puertas de Invernalia totalmente sola, años después de que todo el mundo la creyera muerta, incluyendo él mismo, pero el regresar a su hogar solamente para encontrarse con que su hermana se ha ido para enfrentar sola la inhospitalidad de los caminos durante el invierno le revuelve el estómago

Words: 4515, Chapters: 1/1, Language: Español

Series: Part 1 of Two roads. One castle

  • Fandoms: A Song of Ice and Fire & Related Fandoms
  • Rating: Not Rated
  • Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings
  • Categories: F/M
  • Characters: Jon Snow | Aegon Targaryen, Arya Stark, Sansa Stark, Tormund Giantsbane, Original Characters
  • Relationships: Jon Snow/Arya Stark
  • Additional Tags: Jon Snow knows nothing, Jon Snow is King in the North, POV Jon Snow, Jealous Jon Snow, Princess Arya Stark

summary: [[MORE]] The end is near. ❄️ In this week's issue, we go behind the scenes of #GameOfThrones — the most secretive series on...
caption:
The end is near. ❄️ In this week’s issue, we go behind the scenes of #GameOfThrones — the most secretive series on television — for the HBO epic’s final season. From an emotional table read to staging the show’s biggest battle yet to a preview of season 8’s mysterious storyline, we have an exclusive first look at the show’s six remaining episodes from the set in Northern Ireland. Click the link in our bio to read our full cover story now. #GoT 📷: Illustration by @f_francavilla for EW.
Via @entertainmentweekly

summary: Visual Storytelling in S8 With no Northern roots of her own, it’s a rare sight to see a Targaryen queen sporting the show’s...
body:
Visual Storytelling in S8

With no Northern roots of her own, it’s a rare sight to see a Targaryen queen sporting the show’s trademarked Northern braids. A simple hairstyle of two braids brought together and twisted has been on screen multiple times, but only been exclusively worn by Northern women until now. 

Adapting to other culture’s style has always been Daenerys; This season is no different, following her philosophy of “Man wants to be the king o’ the rabbits, he best wear a pair o’ floppy ears.“ Yet, it’s this particular cut of her cloak and style of hair that lets us know she’s not only pining for Northern approval, but that of the Stark family and Sansa most of all.

Her white coat is akin to the design of the last one, but with red lining and a red cloak lined with fur. Worn like this, it’s a closer look to the original design Costume designer Michelle Clapton had sketched out.

And of course, it must be white. Clapton explained the color choice as a “definite shift in her look as [Dany] embarks on the mission of aiding Jon’s team trapped north of the Wall.” Michelle has also said that Daenerys’ season 7 wardrobe grew into greys, blues, whites, and stapled with fur to symbolize her “growing affection for the King in the North.” Expect Season 8′s to be more dramatically pronounced of that affection as ever.

While show critics make good points that the entire shift of color-to-black wardrobe in season 7 is not a good reflection of George R.R Martins lively characters, the shift to black was explained as a reflection that “winter is here.” Daenerys shift to white, to help Jon beyond the wall, is not only a reflection of her affection for the KiTN, but of her new commitment. Her wardrobe no longer reflects back on the Throne aspirations of her brother, but a new priority; Killing the white walkers and bringing forward the Spring.

On Jon’s part, at first, I thought he was dressed for a normal occasion. I was confused, because this season is coming storm, a battle of humanity against winter, and he is not wearing his armor. Most noticeably, his iron gorget with two snarling direwolves is missing.  

But Jon’s attire here is not a man’s formal tunic. It’s not soft, or embroidered, or woolen. It’s not a look for a king or a lord lounging around in a castle. This is the look of a man in wartime. 

He has leather jerkin, and a tough, tunic underneath. He is wearing some armor, just not the traditional Stark look he took after becoming King. This is not the trademarked Northern armor of the Starks, this is a different Jon. 

Season 7 marked a peak for Jon’s confidence in himself as a king and as a part of the Stark family. He imitates his father and brother’s style and flaunts the snarling direwolves with pride.

But from the look of leaked pictures of the set, at some point, he wears his Stark armor in the show, but still missing that Stark gorget. This Season 8 Jon resembles Season 6 Jon the most. Not quite a Stark. Unsure of what he is or where he belongs. No direwolves in sight, for a man distraught and unsure of himself. 

Yet it’s possible that the simplicity of this black costume reflects back on Jon accepting his Targaryen heritage. It’s possible that Jon has some Targaryen-theme armor to piece together the look, and was opted out of this photoshoot to prevent spoilers. What they couldn’t hide were the Targaryen scale details, similar to those Dany has worn throughout the seasons. 

Despite his Targaryen side, the new Northern cloak pieces the whole look together and flaunts Jon’s roots in Winterfell. This is all enhanced by Jon’s bun, an imitation of his father’s style, and an homage of the figure Jon wants to live up to. 

Arya undergoes only a slighter shift. Her armor is finer, with studded details befitting of a warrior in the Northern upper class. Like Season 6-7 Jon, she is mirroring her father’s style. Her hair becomes softer, wispier, curlier, and more romantic, no longer the harsh, pulled back hairstyle worn in times of inner conflict.  

Cersei is here for war. Decorating her dresses with golden armor and continuing the trend of trying to imitate her father. Hers is a fight for the throne, not the fight for life. It’s clear she will not fight against the white walkers.  Her devotion to her throne and status will be her end, for hands of gold are always cold, and winter has arrived.

He has leather jerkin, and a tough, tunic underneath. He is wearing some armor, just not the traditional Stark look he took after becoming King. This is not the trademarked Northern armor of the Starks, this is a different Jon. 

Season 7 marked a peak for Jon’s confidence in himself as a king and as a part of the Stark family. He imitates his father and brother’s style and flaunts the snarling direwolves with pride.

But from the look of leaked pictures of the set, at some point, he wears his Stark armor in the show, but still missing that Stark gorget. This Season 8 Jon resembles Season 6 Jon the most. Not quite a Stark. Unsure of what he is or where he belongs. No direwolves in sight, for a man distraught and unsure of himself. 

Yet it’s possible that the simplicity of this black costume reflects back on Jon accepting his Targaryen heritage. It’s possible that Jon has some Targaryen-theme armor to piece together the look, and was opted out of this photoshoot to prevent spoilers. What they couldn’t hide were the Targaryen scale details, similar to those Dany has worn throughout the seasons. 

Despite his Targaryen side, the new Northern cloak pieces the whole look together and flaunts Jon’s roots in Winterfell. This is all enhanced by Jon’s bun, an imitation of his father’s style, and an homage of the figure Jon wants to live up to. 

Arya undergoes only a slighter shift. Her armor is finer, with studded details befitting of a warrior in the Northern upper class. Like Season 6-7 Jon, she is mirroring her father’s style. Her hair becomes softer, wispier, curlier, and more romantic, no longer the harsh, pulled back hairstyle worn in times of inner conflict.  

Cersei is here for war. Decorating her dresses with golden armor and continuing the trend of trying to imitate her father. Hers is a fight for the throne, not the fight for life. It’s clear she will not fight against the white walkers.  Her devotion to her throne and status will be her end, for hands of gold are always cold, and winter has arrived.

trail.content_raw:
Visual Storytelling in S8

With no Northern roots of her own, it’s a rare sight to see a Targaryen queen sporting the show’s trademarked Northern braids. A simple hairstyle of two braids brought together and twisted has been on screen multiple times, but only been exclusively worn by Northern women until now. 

Adapting to other culture’s style has always been Daenerys; This season is no different, following her philosophy of “Man wants to be the king o’ the rabbits, he best wear a pair o’ floppy ears.“ Yet, it’s this particular cut of her cloak and style of hair that lets us know she’s not only pining for Northern approval, but that of the Stark family and Sansa most of all.

Her white coat is akin to the design of the last one, but with red lining and a red cloak lined with fur. Worn like this, it’s a closer look to the original design Costume designer Michelle Clapton had sketched out.

And of course, it must be white. Clapton explained the color choice as a “definite shift in her look as [Dany] embarks on the mission of aiding Jon’s team trapped north of the Wall.” Michelle has also said that Daenerys’ season 7 wardrobe grew into greys, blues, whites, and stapled with fur to symbolize her “growing affection for the King in the North.” Expect Season 8′s to be more dramatically pronounced of that affection as ever.

While show critics make good points that the entire shift of color-to-black wardrobe in season 7 is not a good reflection of George R.R Martins lively characters, the shift to black was explained as a reflection that “winter is here.” Daenerys shift to white, to help Jon beyond the wall, is not only a reflection of her affection for the KiTN, but of her new commitment. Her wardrobe no longer reflects back on the Throne aspirations of her brother, but a new priority; Killing the white walkers and bringing forward the Spring.

On Jon’s part, at first, I thought he was dressed for a normal occasion. I was confused, because this season is coming storm, a battle of humanity against winter, and he is not wearing his armor. Most noticeably, his iron gorget with two snarling direwolves is missing.  

But Jon’s attire here is not a man’s formal tunic. It’s not soft, or embroidered, or woolen. It’s not a look for a king or a lord lounging around in a castle. This is the look of a man in wartime. 

He has leather jerkin, and a tough, tunic underneath. He is wearing some armor, just not the traditional Stark look he took after becoming King. This is not the trademarked Northern armor of the Starks, this is a different Jon. 

Season 7 marked a peak for Jon’s confidence in himself as a king and as a part of the Stark family. He imitates his father and brother’s style and flaunts the snarling direwolves with pride.

But from the look of leaked pictures of the set, at some point, he wears his Stark armor in the show, but still missing that Stark gorget. This Season 8 Jon resembles Season 6 Jon the most. Not quite a Stark. Unsure of what he is or where he belongs. No direwolves in sight, for a man distraught and unsure of himself. 

Yet it’s possible that the simplicity of this black costume reflects back on Jon accepting his Targaryen heritage. It’s possible that Jon has some Targaryen-theme armor to piece together the look, and was opted out of this photoshoot to prevent spoilers. What they couldn’t hide were the Targaryen scale details, similar to those Dany has worn throughout the seasons. 

Despite his Targaryen side, the new Northern cloak pieces the whole look together and flaunts Jon’s roots in Winterfell. This is all enhanced by Jon’s bun, an imitation of his father’s style, and an homage of the figure Jon wants to live up to. 

Arya undergoes only a slighter shift. Her armor is finer, with studded details befitting of a warrior in the Northern upper class. Like Season 6-7 Jon, she is mirroring her father’s style. Her hair becomes softer, wispier, curlier, and more romantic, no longer the harsh, pulled back hairstyle worn in times of inner conflict.  

Cersei is here for war. Decorating her dresses with golden armor and continuing the trend of trying to imitate her father. Hers is a fight for the throne, not the fight for life. It’s clear she will not fight against the white walkers.  Her devotion to her throne and status will be her end, for hands of gold are always cold, and winter has arrived.
trail.content:

summary: The 5 GoT spin-offs if I got to plan them
title: The 5 GoT spin-offs if I got to plan them
body:
1. The one that plays thousands of years earlier is nothing but a 5 hour psychedelic dreamscape telling a mythological story about dragons. Great music though.

2. Brienne and Podrick solve crimes. Weekly procedural. 10 seasons.

3. A day-to-day documentation of the weeks Sandor and Arya spent walking around the countryside in season 4. Nothing much happens. Just endless wood- and grasslands and their running commentary. Every episode is 2 hours long and has zero dramatic tension. Kind of like a Let’s Play: Westeros. People watch for the one-liners.

4. A reality show in which Varys, Cersei and Tyrion travel around the continent as wine experts, tasting wines and giving unwanted advice to winemakers. Tywinn has to pay for the whole thing and thus a considerable amount of time each episode is spent on him reacting to the footage.

5. The adventures of Jon Snow, except the whole thing is shot from Ghost’s perspective and Ghost’s inner monologue is the narrator. He is voiced by Arnold Schwarzenegger. Everyone hates the show but can’t stop watching.

blog.name: reddragon1995
blog.title: Jonerys Snowstorm Of House Stargaryen
blog.description: HE LOVED HER AND SHE LOVED HIM

body:
The REVEAL

I spend a lot of time thinking about how the revelation of Jon’s parentage is gonna go, so I’d love to see what my fellow Jon and Dany and Jonerys fans think. Poll questions to follow:

1) WHO WILL REVEAL THE TRUTH?

A) Bran

B) Sam

C) Bran and Sam together

D) Howland Reed (even though we’ve never really seen or heard of him on the show except the TOJ fight?)

E) Someone else ….. Who though?

2) HOW WILL DAENERYS FIND OUT?

A) She will find out at the same time as Jon (they will be told together)

B) Jon will tell her

C) Someone will tell her after Jon finds out, but before everyone else finds out

D) She will find out when everyone else does

E) She will never find out

3) ASSUMING BRAN BREAKS THE NEWS, HOW WILL THAT GO?

A) He’ll spit that shit out with the tact of Siri giving driving directions

B) He will actually try to give some context and backstory

C) Sam will be there with the exposition and emotional support

4) WHO ELSE WILL LEARN THE TRUTH?

A) Jon only

B) Jon and Dany only

C) Team Stark and Team Targaryen

D) Errrybody gonna know that shit

5) HOW WILL JON REACT?

A) Disbelief and anger at first but then he accepts it

B) He pushes everyone away and sulks for 4 episodes

C) He shrugs it off and says he has more important things to worry about

D) He embraces that shit, like “I know who I am now!” And starts calling himself Aegon Targaryen

E) Epic Winterfell Sex with the hot auntie

6) HOW WILL DANY REACT?

A) This little motherfucker is gonna steal my thunder? I don’t fucking think so! So, anger, mistrust, jealousy?

B) She’ll be the one to console Jon

C) I don’t even care, I still love him

D) I’m not the last. My family hasn’t seen its end.

E) She’ll take her army and dragons and go home.

I also wonder how Team Stark and Team Targaryen react, and how the Northern Lords and Cersei will react if they find out. Acceptance? Fear? Joy for the Targaryen Restoration? Distrust?

Please reblog/respond

summary: The first photo from Season 8 is on the cover of Entertainment Weekly. No spoilers, it just looks like Daenerys finally got a...
caption:
The first photo from Season 8 is on the cover of Entertainment Weekly.

No spoilers, it just looks like Daenerys finally got a sensible coat for Westerosi weather.

Read the cover story here.

summary: You know what I find strange? There’s not one mention of a heartfelt reunion happening in episode 1 of season 8 between Jon and...
body: You know what I find strange? There’s not one mention of a heartfelt reunion happening in episode 1 of season 8 between Jon and Arya NOT ONE! The EW article solely focuses on the tension within the first episode and angst between Jon and Sansa over Dany. I think that’s wild, considering that people have been anticipating this reunion since season 1. From what I gather it seems like even when the reunion happens it’s gonna be overshadowed by the tension/drama to ensue. Someone on here once predicted that Jon and Arya’s reunion was going to go left and I’m starting to agree. I don’t think their reunion is going to be hostile but I definitely don’t think it’s going to be this emotional tear-jerker either. I thinks it’s going to be somewhere in the middle and I think most people will be extremely disappointed.
